Author: Alexfrog#1338
Content: For Pirate, I am concerned that in about 5 years, the mining rewards will become too small and we wont have much hashrate left at all to protect the network.  Has anybody discussed a tail emission?

Author: Alexfrog#1338
Content: We dont want to have hashrate so low that its just a few computers running it, because the reward is a fraction of one coin.  Then its basically free to just keep up a 51% attack in perpetuity.    DPoW will tell us this is happening, yes, but if it just goes on forever its a problem.

Author: Alexfrog#1338
Content: Yes, IF transaction fees can cover the cost then its fine, but that puts a clock on when the coin needs to have wide adoption by

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if there is a permanent censor attack going then this is a permanent cost to the attacker without any gain. In that case, then the "txfee" would be the cost to rent enough has to mine a block with the pending tx. just one honest block can be mining the mempool tx

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so a 100% censorshipt attack would be inordinately expensive and without a profit motive, unsustainable

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if we are to be worried about uneconomic attacks, then there is always the "kill the internet" attack. but i dont spend much time worrying about such things

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: @PTYX  there are some major issues with local currency systems.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Taxes are one , as they are due in the legal tender currency,  the other is devaluation.  Currency in circulation can‚Äôt leave quickly due to the limited ability of the local community( and more specifically those who take part in the program )  to supply enough  goods/services to clear the money

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: yeah i just thought it was interesting. i'm sure it comes with problems

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: They do apply. Barter is taxable in the US and most other countries. You control the emission but you don‚Äôt control the ‚Äúreflux‚Äù. The rate which currency in circulation returns to the issuer.  This is important because in these types of systems the currency is ‚Äúcredit‚Äù  which has a corresponding ‚Äúdebt‚Äù. if there is too much in circulation,  merchants will want more than face value because their need of the local currency is less.  As they have accumulated much and have had little to spend it on.  I‚Äôve seen this with many barter exchange systems.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Most countries have a form of money

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: If you had something worth 10 dollars and traded for something worth 20.  The difference is capital gains.  Direct barter is hard to track,  just like a lot of things you are supposed to report it but many don‚Äôt.  In a centrally run operation where there is a 3rd party responsible for the record keeping typically they report it.    You may be in an area without capital gains tax or where barter is exempt,  I know though it is regulated by most countries though ,  they have their own lobby and everything,  IRTA

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: With money

Content: Other sources

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: I know it‚Äôs dumb I don‚Äôt agree with it but they clamped down on barter in the west decades ago

Content: USA , EU, UK, UAE, India, China Japan Australia New Zealand and many others have laws regarding barter
